content.body: This test seems to expect _non-initial_ about:blank (which in Chrome fires its load event async) to have the magic characteristic of the DOM getting built (i.e. `contentDocument.body` existing) synchronously when the location has updated: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/ab53b6abd671656733e41ef03cd0be11250688d7/content-security-policy/inheritance/history-iframe.sub.html#L53-L63 Is there a legitimate Web compat need for this magic?

content.body: hsivonen: Well it would only equal `about:blank` after the navigation is complete/loaded, right? And that's async, as per what I'm observing.

content.body: Domenic: do you know how css module scripts work (in particular if they always create a new `CSSStyleSheet` object)? See https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7002#issuecomment-1146198613

content.body: Kiiiinnda looks like they just always do? https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#creating-a-css-module-script
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Kiiiinnda looks like they just always do? https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#creating-a-css-module-script

content.body: it always creates a stylesheet object, but the ES algo it passes that to only uses that value if you haven't already done a css import from that url. If you have it just grabs the existing value.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: it always creates a stylesheet object, but the ES algo it passes that to only uses that value if you haven't already done a css import from that url. If you have it just grabs the existing value.

content.body: But it remains that all of this work is observable (such as via a proxy on the CSSStyleSheet prototype, I think), whereas JS module creation is *not* observable, so the model used by JS isn't great here.
content.formatted_body: But it remains that all of this work is observable (such as via a proxy on the CSSStyleSheet prototype, I think), whereas JS module creation is not observable, so the model used by JS isn't great here.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: But it remains that all of this work is observable (such as via a proxy on the CSSStyleSheet prototype, I think), whereas JS module creation is *not* observable, so the model used by JS isn't great here.

But it remains that all of this work is observable (such as via a proxy on the CSSStyleSheet prototype, I think), whereas JS module creation is not observable, so the model used by JS isn't great here.
